answers.answer: To receive free laboratory tests, patients need a referral ticket from their family medicine doctor or a specialist doctor working under an agreement with their respective healthcare insurance provider. They should also visit a laboratory having an agreement with their health insurance company.
answers.bResponse: To receive free laboratory tests, patients need a referral ticket from their family medicine doctor or a specialist doctor working under an agreement with their respective healthcare insurance provider. They should also visit a laboratory having an agreement with their health insurance company. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/laboratory-analysis

answers.answer: To benefit from free laboratory analysis and imaging investigations, patients should visit a laboratory that has a contract with their respective health insurance companies. These facilities will provide them with necessary testing services upon presentation of a referral ticket issued by their family medicine doctors or specialists under agreement with the insurer.

answers.answer: The following types of laboratory tests are covered by the health insurance system: hematological (such as hemograms), serum (e.g., uric acid, serum creatinine, blood sugar, cholesterol, triglycerides, sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium), urine (including urine summary and sediment, urinary albumin, urinary glucose), immunological (various hormones and antibodies), microbiological (antibiotic resistance testing), examination of sampled tissues, and the Papanicolaou test. Additionally, radiology analyzes (e.g., CT, MRI, and angiography) and non-radiative investigations (e.g., ultrasounds and dopplers) are included under the scope of coverage provided by the health insurance system.
answers.bResponse: The following types of laboratory tests are covered by the health insurance system: hematological (such as hemograms), serum (e.g., uric acid, serum creatinine, blood sugar, cholesterol, triglycerides, sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium), urine (including urine summary and sediment, urinary albumin, urinary glucose), immunological (various hormones and antibodies), microbiological (antibiotic resistance testing), examination of sampled tissues, and the Papanicolaou test. Additionally, radiology analyzes (e.g., CT, MRI, and angiography) and non-radiative investigations (e.g., ultrasounds and dopplers) are included under the scope of coverage provided by the health insurance system. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/laboratory-analysis

answers.answer: The mentioned categories include Radiologic procedures, such as CT scans, MRIs, Scintigraphy, Angiography, Dopplers, and non-radiative investigations under the Health Insurance System.
answers.bResponse: The mentioned categories include Radiologic procedures, such as CT scans, MRIs, Scintigraphy, Angiography, Dopplers, and non-radiative investigations under the Health Insurance System. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/laboratory-analysis

answers.answer: Papanicolaou tests, commonly known as Pap smears or simply Paps, are a type of gynecological screening procedure used for detecting abnormal cells on the cervix which could potentially develop into cervical cancer if left untreated. The test involves collecting a sample of cells from the surface of the cervix with a small brush or spatula and examining them under a microscope to identify any abnormalities. If necessary, further testing may be performed based on the results of the Pap smear.
answers.bResponse: Papanicolaou tests, commonly known as Pap smears or simply Paps, are a type of gynecological screening procedure used for detecting abnormal cells on the cervix which could potentially develop into cervical cancer if left untreated. If necessary, further testing may be performed based on the results of the Pap smear. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/laboratory-analysis

answers.answer: Patients can find information on the CNAS website regarding the contact details of the providers, specifically those offering different types of medical assistance. They can also locate the list of laboratories with health insurance company contracts and the corresponding funds available for use. Additionally, they can read the "Manual of Rights" in Romanian on this website.

answers.answer: Within 5 calendar days from the date of the request, providers of paraclinical medical services must carry out the following investigations: 1) those recommended according to the medical practice guidelines approved by order of the Minister of Health, necessary for the monitoring of patients with COVID-19; 2) patients with oncological diseases; 3) diabetes; 4) rare diseases; 5) cardiovascular diseases; 6) cerebrovascular diseases; 7) neurological diseases; 8) services that are provided by laboratories even if they exceed the contract value, provided that the prescribing physician specifies on the referral note that the investigations are carried out for monitoring.
answers.bResponse: Within 5 calendar days from the date of the request, providers of paraclinical medical services must carry out the following investigations: 1) those recommended according to the medical practice guidelines approved by order of the Minister of Health, necessary for the monitoring of patients with COVID-19; 2) patients with oncological diseases; 3) diabetes; 4) rare diseases; 5) cardiovascular diseases; 6) cerebrovascular diseases; 7) neurological diseases; 8) services that are provided by laboratories even if they exceed the contract value, provided that the prescribing physician specifies on the referral note that the investigations are carried out for monitoring. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/laboratory-analysis

answers.answer: Chronic diseases, such as oncological diseases, diabetes, rare diseases, cardiovascular diseases, cerebrovascular diseases, and neurological diseases, as well as investigations involving tissue collection, can have a validity period of up to 90 days when referred through a lab investigation note.
answers.bResponse: Chronic diseases, such as oncological diseases, diabetes, rare diseases, cardiovascular diseases, cerebrovascular diseases, and neurological diseases, as well as investigations involving tissue collection, can have a validity period of up to 90 days when referred through a lab investigation note.
